awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Development of Interest in Computer Science: An Experience Sampling Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores STEM interest development at the undergraduate level in computer science. It is a study of national importance that will focus on substantial differences in who pursues an interest, a major, or an occupation in computer science. The pilot study will look at what drives these differences at a level where policymakers and educators seeking to support and sustain a more representative population of computer science experts can most effectively act. To address this problem, the project will conduct a pilot study that articulates a fundamental research project appropriate for the ECR program using the experience sampling method (ESM). In order to meet the ECR threshold for research, the investigator will enlist mentors and advisory board members with expertise using this methodology to help identify experiences, expertise, and competencies the investigator will need to develop during the two-year project period. Building on advice of these experts, the investigator will receive assistance in study design, research methods, and data analysis. A deeper understanding in these broad categories will help the investigator use a variety of approaches and measures to examine students' individual characteristics, construct surveys, study variation in students' experiences, and structure timelines for the ESM study. Through the professional development plan, the investigator will address these needs by participating in subject-specific conferences, workshops, short courses, research groups, and mentoring activities in both research methodology and computer science relative to STEM interest development.

The pilot study will be carried out in the context of an introductory undergraduate computer science course using a pool of 200 students. It will be framed in terms of the interest development theory to better understand how students' in-the-moment interest is sparked in specific situations and then accumulates into more ongoing and sustained individual interest. Specifically, ESM will allow the investigator to monitor a short-term intervention to explore how situational interest may change over time into well-developed individual interest. The pilot study will seek to determine if this method is more suitable for understanding situational interest and if so, under what conditions. Data will be collected through pre-post surveys, an experience sampling survey, and short written reports. Data will be analyzed using multivariate, mixed effects models that will consider the relationship between situational and individual interest. Outcomes from this project will be two-fold: an advancement in the investigator's methodological knowledge relative to ESM; and a deeper understanding about how student's interest may develop in computer science as well as what barriers might interfere with such development. The project is supported through the EHR Core Research Building Capacity in STEM Education Research competition that is designed to build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview


This project focused on building the investigator's expertise in using and analyzing data from the Experience Sampling Method (ESM), a technique that involves short repeated surveys intended to measure individuals' experiences. The empirical focus of this project was the collection of data on undergraduate students' interest in introductory computer science classes. Broadly, ESM permitted the analyses of data on students' interests (and other aspects of their motivation) in a finer-grained, more dynamic way than is typically possible through the use of pre-post surveys.


Intellectual Merit


In computer science education, the project's findings emphasized the critical role of self-efficacy and interest in shaping URM students' momentary experiences and academic outcomes. The research demonstrated that momentary experiences significantly influence students' interest in computing and course outcomes, with baseline self-efficacy being a notable predictor of end-of-course grades for under-represented minority (URM) students. Additionally, the project explored the shifts in teachers' social media use for professional learning during the COVID-19 pandemic as well as shifts in students' experiences during this time, offering insights into how to support both educators and crises during crises and within online learning environments.


Another aspect project involved understanding the variability in students' situational engagement in science learning environments. Through intensive longitudinal methods, the research quantified the sources of variability in learners' cognitive, behavioral, and affective engagement. The study revealed that individual learners accounted for the greatest variation in engagement, with situational and classroom factors also contributing but to a lesser extent. This finding underscores the individualized nature of engagement and the need for educational approaches that cater to the diverse experiences of students.
As an extension of the work in computer science education, we collected data from undergraduate life science students' on their experience of anxiety. This extension has the potential to reveal the dynamic nature of students' anxiety.


Broader Impacts


The findings on the importance of self-efficacy and interest for URM students in computer science courses provide a foundation for interventions aimed at enhancing the inclusivity and effectiveness of computer science education, potentially reducing gender disparities in the field.We developed an open-source tool for conducting ESM studies, called Short Message Survey. This is available on GitHub for anyone in the world to use to to survey students in an ESM mode in a relatively unobtrusive, efficient way: through individuals' phones.
In addition to sharing the Short Message Survey app, we shared all journal articles and conference presentations in an open and accessible manner. We will share analytic code and data related to the project via the following Open Science Framework project: https://osf.io/yau4q/.


The project has provided the PI, two post-doctoral scholars, and a doctoral student with professional development opportunities and the opportunity to build a record of conference presentations and proceedings papers and journal article presentations. It has also led to several collaborations centering on the use of ESM.


Sharing of Project Findings


The dissemination of the project's results through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and collaborations has ensured that the insights gained reach a wide audience across educational research and practice communities. Specifically, findings were shared in AERA Open, Science & Education, and the International Journal of STEM Education, and in the proceedings of the International Computing Education Research and Special Interest Groups for Computer science Education conferences.


Last Modified: 01/28/2024
Modified by: Joshua Rosenberg
